question: Which of the following tests is most sensitive and specific test during antenatal check-up for a pregnant lady with family history of Thalassemia?
exp: Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test - NESTROFT (sensitive but less specific) Hemoglobin electrophoresis does not give quanititative results for different Hb fractions HPLC (High performance liquid chromatography), best among the options given HPLC gives HbA2 percentage. HbA2 > 4% (3.5-8%) is diagnostic of thalassemia trait, along with microcytic hypochromic red cells indices CBC findings - Thalassemia trait Microcytic hypochromic red cells Normal or mildly increased RDW Target cells Increased red cell count Normal Hb or mild anemia

question: Which of the following shows breast necrosis and calcification?
exp: Breast cancer: Bilateral tendency - lobular carcinoma Breast cancer at microscopic level - ductal carcinoma Breast necrosis with calcification - Comedo subtype of DCIS (Cheese like appearance of necrotic material within the duct) Comedo DCIS: More often it is detected on mammography as clustered or linear and branching Areas of calcification defined by two features 1. Pleomorphic grade nuclei 2. Areas of central necrosis Cribriform DCIS: May have rounded ( cookie cutter like ) spaces within the ducts, or a solid DCIS Pattern Micropapillary DCIS: Produces bulbous protrusions without a fibrovascular core often arranged in Complex intra ducted patterns Cribriform DCIS Micro papillary DCIS

question: Which of the following has a polygenic pattern of inheritance?
exp: Polygenic pattern It occurs when one characteristic is controlled by two or more genes -Diabetes mellitus Autosomal dominant : Familial hypercholesterolemia X linked recessive G6pD X linked dominant: Resistant rickets

question: All of the following special histology stains are used to demonstrate H. pylori in gastric biopsies, except:
exp: Fite's Acid fast stain (Fite-Faraco staining) is used for detection of Lepra bacilli (M. leprae) The following stains are used for detection of Helicobacter pylori in biopsies and tissue specimens: Routine hematoxylin & eosin (H&E) stain Special stains: Giemsa Wahin-Starry Pap stain Genta Modified Steiner Diff-Quik

question: Which of the following condition is characterized by presence pf hyaline deposits in alveolar walls?
exp: Neonates HMD ( Hyaline membrane disease composition:- fibrin ) Respiratory distress syndrome Adults ARDS(Adult respiratory distress syndrome) Usually caused due to damage of endothelial cells Subsequently injury to TYPE 1 and TYPE 2 pneumocytes ARDS:- Characterized by Acute shoness of breath Hypoxemia Diffuse pulmonary infiltrates Diagnosis of ARDS : onset <7 days Non cardiogenic pulmonary edema B/L diffuse infiltrates on chest X-ray Pao2 < 60 mmHg Pao2/Fio2 < 60mmHg Hyaline membrane disease: -Deposition of layer of hyaline proteinaceous material in peripheral airspaces of infants 200-300 (Mild ARDS) 100-200 (Moderate ARDS) < 100 Severe ARDS Causes of RDS: immaturity of lungs (most impoant substrate on which RDS develops) Occurs in about 60% of infants born <28 wks Occurs in 30% of infants born b/w 28-34 wks Fundamental defect in RDS is deficiency of pulmonary surfactant (predominantly dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline smaller amounts of phosphatidyl glycerol) Interstitial lung disease: Predominant involvement of interstitium progressing to fibrosis IOC: HRCT chest Radiological pattern: Reticular pattern CT chest: mild lazy ness K/a ground glass opacity

question: Which type of anemia is seen in patients of rheumatoid ahritis?
exp: Rheumatoid ahritis is a chronic inflammatory condition of joints. Anemia of chronic inflammation is found in RA. Majority have normocytic normochromic anemia. A small subset may have microcytic hypochromic anemia.

question: Rolling of leucocytes on endothelial cells is mediated by which of the following proteins?
exp: Rolling interactions of leucocytes are mediated by a family of proteins called as selectins 3 types of selectins: L - selectins ( on leucocytes ) , E - selectin ( on endothelium ), P-selectin ( On platelets, endothelium ) Integrins: Firm adhesion of leucocyte to endothelial cell is mediated by family of leucocyte surface proteins called as integrins Transferrin: Iron transpoing protein PECAM-1: (platelet endothelium cell adhesion molecule): Present in the inter-cellular junction between endothelial cells Help in migration of leucocytes
